snippet: President Obama on Friday defended government efforts to gather telephone and Internet data, and sought to reassure Americans that his administration was not listening in on their calls.
abstract: Pres Obama offers robust defense of newly revealed surveillance programs as more classified secrets spill into public; seeks to reassure Americans that his administration is not listening in on their calls; issue complicates summit meeting with Chinese Pres Xi Jinping focused partly on human rights and cybersecurity.

byline.original: By PETER BAKER and DAVID E. SANGER
byline.contributor: David E. Sanger contributed reporting from Washington, and Jackie Calmes from San Jose, Calif.

lead_paragraph: President Obama on Friday defended government efforts to gather telephone and Internet data, and sought to reassure Americans that his administration was not listening in on their calls.

headline.main: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
